elements.content: Three one-dimensional methyl-substituted cucurbituril-based polyrotaxanes, [Ag(H2O)(C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)3H2O (1), [Cu(H2O)2Cl2(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2H2O (2), and [Ag2(H2O)3(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2(NO3)14H2O (3) have been prepared with N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4N3) and N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butane diamine (C4N4), incorporating a symmetrical α,α′,δ,δ′-tetramethyl-cucurbit[6]uril (TMeQ[6]) using methods assisted by silver(I) and copper(II) ions. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that all three polyrotaxanes have basically 1D linear chain structures with different shapes. However, the π···π stacking of the protruded pyridyl ring of the guest is observed and leads to the formation of two-dimensional networks in compound 1. Unlike most cases in which a metal ion coordinates to both of the terminal pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two neighboring pseudorotaxanes, the silver ion coordinates to only one terminal pyridyl nitrogen atom and simultaneously coordinates to two carbonyl oxygen atoms of the neighboring Q[6], leading to the formation of the 1D supramolecular chain in compound 3.
elements.clean_text: Three one-dimensional methyl-substituted cucurbituril-based polyrotaxanes, [Ag(H2O)(C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)3H2O (1), [Cu(H2O)2Cl2(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2H2O (2), and [Ag2(H2O)3(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2(NO3)14H2O (3) have been prepared with N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4N3) and N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butane diamine (C4N4), incorporating a symmetrical α,α',δ,δ'-tetramethyl-cucurbit[6]uril (TMeQ[6]) using methods assisted by silver(I) and copper(II) ions. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that all three polyrotaxanes have basically 1D linear chain structures with different shapes. However, the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking of the protruded pyridyl ring of the guest is observed and leads to the formation of two-dimensional networks in compound 1. Unlike most cases in which a metal ion coordinates to both of the terminal pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two neighboring pseudorotaxanes, the silver ion coordinates to only one terminal pyridyl nitrogen atom and simultaneously coordinates to two carbonyl oxygen atoms of the neighboring Q[6], leading to the formation of the 1D supramolecular chain in compound 3.

elements.content: Three one-dimensional methyl-substituted cucurbituril-based polyrotaxanes have been prepared with N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4N3) and N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butane diamine (C4N4), incorporating a symmetrical α,α′,δ,δ′-tetramethyl-cucurbit[6]uril (TMeQ[6]) using methods assisted by silver(I) and copper(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: Three one-dimensional methyl-substituted cucurbituril-based polyrotaxanes have been prepared with N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4N3) and N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butane diamine (C4N4), incorporating a symmetrical α,α',δ,δ'-tetramethyl-cucurbit[6]uril (TMeQ[6]) using methods assisted by silver(I) and copper(II) ions.

elements.content: Much attention has been focused on the design and synthesis of interlocked molecules such as rotaxanes, catenanes, and molecular knots, the attraction being aesthetics as well as the potential for nanoscale applications toward molecular devices and new materials. In Q[n] chemistry, these types of structures were first realized by threading cucurbituril (Q[6]) molecules with N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-diaminobutane dihydrochloride and then allowing the resulting pseudorotaxane to react with Cu(NO3)2 to form a one-dimensional coordination polymer by Kim and co-workers in 1996. Later, using this strategy, Kim and co-workers demonstrated a series of novel Q[6]-based coordination polymers, such as the two-dimensional polycatenated polyrotaxane nets, based on the formation of a pseudorotaxane by threading Q[6] with N,N′-bis(3-cyanobenzyl)-1,4-diaminobutane dinitrate, followed by the reaction of the pseudorotaxane with AgNO3. Similarly, they prepared 3D polyrotaxane frameworks based on the formation of a pseudorotaxane by threading Q[6] with the same string guest, followed by treatment with Tb(NO3)3 under hydrothermal conditions. The most interesting feature of these coordination polymers is called the “molecular necklace” formed by treating the pseudorotaxane of Q[6] and a “string” guest having suitable functional groups at both ends with Pt(en)-(NO3)2 (en = ethylenediamine). Since these reports, no related work has been published until 2008, when Chen and co-workers demonstrated a series of one-dimensional coordination polymers based on the coordination of metal ions with some pseudorotaxanes. Until now, all such coordination polymers are based on the normal cucurbituril, namely Q[6].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Much attention has been focused on the design and synthesis of interlocked molecules such as rotaxanes, catenanes, and molecular knots, the attraction being aesthetics as well as the potential for nanoscale applications toward molecular devices and new materials. In Q[n] chemistry, these types of structures were first realized by threading cucurbituril (Q[6]) molecules with N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-diaminobutane dihydrochloride and then allowing the resulting pseudorotaxane to react with Cu(NO3)2 to form a one-dimensional coordination polymer by Kim and co-workers in 1996. Later, using this strategy, Kim and co-workers demonstrated a series of novel Q[6]-based coordination polymers, such as the two-dimensional polycatenated polyrotaxane nets, based on the formation of a pseudorotaxane by threading Q[6] with N,N'-bis(3-cyanobenzyl)-1,4-diaminobutane dinitrate, followed by the reaction of the pseudorotaxane with AgNO3. Similarly, they prepared 3D polyrotaxane frameworks based on the formation of a pseudorotaxane by threading Q[6] with the same string guest, followed by treatment with Tb(NO3)3 under hydrothermal conditions. The most interesting feature of these coordination polymers is called the "molecular necklace" formed by treating the pseudorotaxane of Q[6] and a "string" guest having suitable functional groups at both ends with Pt(en)-(NO3)2 (en = ethylenediamine). Since these reports, no related work has been published until 2008, when Chen and co-workers demonstrated a series of one-dimensional coordination polymers based on the coordination of metal ions with some pseudorotaxanes. Until now, all such coordination polymers are based on the normal cucurbituril, namely Q[6].

elements.content: In recent years, our group has focused on the synthesis of alky-substituted cucurbit[n]urils, in particular, the partial methyl- or cyclohexano-substituted cucurbit[n]urils, because this partial substitution avoids the problem that the fully substituted Q[n] suffer the limitation that Q[5] is always the major product. It also precludes the need to obtain large quantities of potentially rare or expensive substituted glycolurils. In addition, the alkyl-substituted cucurbit[n]urils have proved to be water-soluble, in particular, cyclohexanocucurbit[n]urils (n = 5, 6), are soluble not only in water but also in some organic solvents. Moreover, the alkyl-substituted cucurbit[n]urils show solid state affinity of the metal ion for the carbonyl oxygen atom of the alkyl-substituted cucurbit[n]urils. Recently, our group has reported a series of supramolecular structures with alkyl-substituted cucurbit[5]urils (SQ[5]s) as “beads” arranged in rings in which the “beads” were also directly interconnected by the metal ions. It suggests a likely increased electron density as a consequence of the electron donating effect of the alkyl substituents.
elements.clean_text: In recent years, our group has focused on the synthesis of alky-substituted cucurbit[n]urils, in particular, the partial methyl- or cyclohexano-substituted cucurbit[n]urils, because this partial substitution avoids the problem that the fully substituted Q[n] suffer the limitation that Q[5] is always the major product. It also precludes the need to obtain large quantities of potentially rare or expensive substituted glycolurils. In addition, the alkyl-substituted cucurbit[n]urils have proved to be water-soluble, in particular, cyclohexanocucurbit[n]urils (n = 5, 6), are soluble not only in water but also in some organic solvents. Moreover, the alkyl-substituted cucurbit[n]urils show solid state affinity of the metal ion for the carbonyl oxygen atom of the alkyl-substituted cucurbit[n]urils. Recently, our group has reported a series of supramolecular structures with alkyl-substituted cucurbit[5]urils (SQ[5]s) as "beads" arranged in rings in which the "beads" were also directly interconnected by the metal ions. It suggests a likely increased electron density as a consequence of the electron donating effect of the alkyl substituents.

elements.content: We first demonstrated the controlled synthesis of the symmetrical tetramethyl-substituted cucurbituril (TMeQ[6], Figure ) by condensing the diether of dimethylglycoluril with the glycoluril dimer. Unlike the cucurbituril (Q[6]), which formed the metal−Q[6] frameworks based on the direct coordination of carbonyl oxygens to the alkali metal ions, TMeQ[6] formed metal−TMeQ[6] frameworks based on the direct coordination of carbonyl oxygens with the alkaline earth metal ions rather than the alkali metal ions. We were interested to determine if the structural architectures of the coordination polymer based on TMeQ[6] could be obtained using the same strategy as mentioned above. In this study, we selected N,N′-bis(n-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4Nn , n = 2,3,4) as the string guest (Scheme ) and prepared pseudorotaxanes and polyrotaxanes with TMeQ[6], followed by treatment with silver or copper ions. In this work, three polyrotaxanes incorporating C4N3@ or C4N4@TMeQ[6] with silver(I) or copper(II) ions are reported.
elements.clean_text: We first demonstrated the controlled synthesis of the symmetrical tetramethyl-substituted cucurbituril (TMeQ[6], Figure ) by condensing the diether of dimethylglycoluril with the glycoluril dimer. Unlike the cucurbituril (Q[6]), which formed the metal-Q[6] frameworks based on the direct coordination of carbonyl oxygens to the alkali metal ions, TMeQ[6] formed metal-TMeQ[6] frameworks based on the direct coordination of carbonyl oxygens with the alkaline earth metal ions rather than the alkali metal ions. We were interested to determine if the structural architectures of the coordination polymer based on TMeQ[6] could be obtained using the same strategy as mentioned above. In this study, we selected N,N'-bis(n-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4Nn , n = 2,3,4) as the string guest (Scheme ) and prepared pseudorotaxanes and polyrotaxanes with TMeQ[6], followed by treatment with silver or copper ions. In this work, three polyrotaxanes incorporating C4N3@ or C4N4@TMeQ[6] with silver(I) or copper(II) ions are reported.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. 1H NMR spectra of the related guests and pseudorotaxanes were recorded on a Varian 400 spectrometer. (H2 C4N3) and (H2 C4N4) were synthesized according to literature procedures, and TMeQ[6] was prepared and purified according to published procedures or those developed in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods

All commercially available chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. 1H NMR spectra of the related guests and pseudorotaxanes were recorded on a Varian 400 spectrometer. (H2 C4N3) and (H2 C4N4) were synthesized according to literature procedures, and TMeQ[6] was prepared and purified according to published procedures or those developed in our laboratory.

elements.content: A mixture of TMeQ[6] (0.41 g, 0.40 mmol) and [(H2 C4N3)(NO3)2] (0.0155 g, 0.40 mmol) in water (15 mL) was heated with stirring at 50 °C for 2 h. The solution was filtered, and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for a period of 2 weeks. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were obtained from the solution with a yield of 30%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.83 (s, 2H), 8.54 (d, 2H), 8.22 (d, 2H), 7.50 (t, 2H), 5.68(d, 12H), 5.52(d, 8H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 2.41 (t, 4H), 1.71 (s, 12H), 0.47 (m, 4H). AgNO3 (13.6 mg, 0.08 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (128 mg, 0.080 mmol) in 10 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8−9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 1 week produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 1 with a yield of 40%. Anal. Calcd for C56H74N29O19Ag: C, 42.97; H, 4.77; N, 25.95. Found: C, 43.06; H, 4.48; N, 26.58.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ag(H2O)(C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)3H2O (1)

A mixture of TMeQ[6] (0.41 g, 0.40 mmol) and [(H2 C4N3)(NO3)2] (0.0155 g, 0.40 mmol) in water (15 mL) was heated with stirring at 50 °C for 2 h. The solution was filtered, and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for a period of 2 weeks. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were obtained from the solution with a yield of 30%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.83 (s, 2H), 8.54 (d, 2H), 8.22 (d, 2H), 7.50 (t, 2H), 5.68(d, 12H), 5.52(d, 8H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 2.41 (t, 4H), 1.71 (s, 12H), 0.47 (m, 4H). AgNO3 (13.6 mg, 0.08 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (128 mg, 0.080 mmol) in 10 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8-9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 1 week produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 1 with a yield of 40%. Anal. Calcd for C56H74N29O19Ag: C, 42.97; H, 4.77; N, 25.95. Found: C, 43.06; H, 4.48; N, 26.58.

elements.content: Crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were prepared by dissolving TMeQ[6] (0.84 g, 0.80 mmol) and [(H2 C4N4)(NO3)2] (0.0320 g, 0.80 mmol) in water (30 mL). The solution was heated for 2 h and then allowed to stand at room temperature. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were obtained from the solution over a period of one week with a yield of 35%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.83 (s, 2H), 8.54 (d, 2H), 8.22 (d, 2H), 7.50 (t, 2H), 5.68 (d, 12H), 5.52 (d, 8H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 2.41 (t, 4H), 1.71 (s, 12H), 0.47 (m, 4H). CuCl2 (13.5 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted to pH = 8−9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 2 weeks produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 2 with a yield of 35%. Anal. Calcd for C56H74N28O16CuCl2: C, 43.97; H, 4.88; N, 25.64. Found: C, 44.17; H, 4.68; N, 25.84.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Cu(H2O)2Cl2(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2H2O (2)

Crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were prepared by dissolving TMeQ[6] (0.84 g, 0.80 mmol) and [(H2 C4N4)(NO3)2] (0.0320 g, 0.80 mmol) in water (30 mL). The solution was heated for 2 h and then allowed to stand at room temperature. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were obtained from the solution over a period of one week with a yield of 35%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.83 (s, 2H), 8.54 (d, 2H), 8.22 (d, 2H), 7.50 (t, 2H), 5.68 (d, 12H), 5.52 (d, 8H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 2.41 (t, 4H), 1.71 (s, 12H), 0.47 (m, 4H). CuCl2 (13.5 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted to pH = 8-9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 2 weeks produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 2 with a yield of 35%. Anal. Calcd for C56H74N28O16CuCl2: C, 43.97; H, 4.88; N, 25.64. Found: C, 44.17; H, 4.68; N, 25.84.

elements.content: AgNO3 (17.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8−9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over 2 days produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 3 with a yield of 25%. Anal. Calcd for C56H100N30O35Ag2: C, 34.15; H, 5.12; N, 21.34. Found: C, 34.27; H, 4.88; N, 22.84.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ag2(H2O)3(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2(NO3)14H2O (3)

AgNO3 (17.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8-9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over 2 days produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 3 with a yield of 25%. Anal. Calcd for C56H100N30O35Ag2: C, 34.15; H, 5.12; N, 21.34. Found: C, 34.27; H, 4.88; N, 22.84.

elements.content: A suitable single crystal (∼0.2 × 0.2 × 0.1 mm3) was picked up with paratone oil and mounted on a Bruker Apex2 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source and a nitrogen cold stream (−50 °C). The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects (SAINT), and semiempirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied (SADABS). The structure was elucidated by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 (SHELXTL). All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were added to their geometrically ideal positions. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for complexes 1−3 are summarized in Table . In addition, the crystallographic data for the reported structures were recorded in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication number (1), (2), (3). These data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccd c.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax +44 1223 336033.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determination of Compounds 1-3 

A suitable single crystal (~0.2 × 0.2 × 0.1 mm3) was picked up with paratone oil and mounted on a Bruker Apex2 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source and a nitrogen cold stream (-50 °C). The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects (SAINT), and semiempirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied (SADABS). The structure was elucidated by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 (SHELXTL). All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were added to their geometrically ideal positions. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for complexes 1-3 are summarized in Table . In addition, the crystallographic data for the reported structures were recorded in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication number (1), (2), (3). These data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccd c.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax +44 1223 336033.

Weighted R on ∣F hkl ∣2: ∑[w(Fo2 − F c 2)2]/∑[w(Fo2)2]1/2.

1H NMR spectra of the inclusion complexes of N,N′-bis(n-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4Nn , n = 2,3,4)@TMeQ[6] reveal that they must first incorporate the pyridyl moieties of the C4Nn guest (molecular dumbbell) and then move on to the butylene moiety and form pseudorotaxane host−guest inclusion complexes. Moreover, the pseudorotaxanes remain stable until the pH of the solution is over 10 (when pH > 10, a large amount of precipitation can be observed). Related investigations of the interaction between TMeQ[6] and C4Nn will be discussed in detail elsewhere.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 1H NMR spectra of the inclusion complexes of N,N'-bis(n-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-butanediamine (C4Nn , n = 2,3,4)@TMeQ[6] reveal that they must first incorporate the pyridyl moieties of the C4Nn  guest (molecular dumbbell) and then move on to the butylene moiety and form pseudorotaxane host-guest inclusion complexes. Moreover, the pseudorotaxanes remain stable until the pH of the solution is over 10 (when pH > 10, a large amount of precipitation can be observed). Related investigations of the interaction between TMeQ[6] and C4Nn  will be discussed in detail elsewhere.

elements.content: It is expected that the structure of the compound 1 is formed with linking by transition metal ions through the coordination with the pyridyl nitrogen atom of the pseudorotaxane C4Nn @Q[6], so generating a polyrotaxane or molecular necklace. Therefore, the reaction of the pseudorotaxane C4N3@TMeQ[6] with silver nitrate was carried out at pH ≈ 8, and the compound 1, with a stoichiometry of [Ag(H2O)(C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)3H2O, was isolated. The X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that an infinite one-dimensional polyrotaxane with square-wave-like shape comprised of the pseudorotaxanes C4N3@TMeQ[6] and the Ag+ cations with a 1:1 ratio of pseudorotaxane to Ag+ ion is present in the crystal structure of compound 1 (Figure ). Each silver ion Ag1 is coordinated to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N25 and N27) from two adjacent pseudorotaxanes with nearly linear coordination geometry, and the N25−Ag1−N27 coordination angle is 171.97°. The two coordinated pyridine planes that have a dihedral angle of 53.60° and the Ag1−N25 bond length of 2.141 Å and the Ag1−N27 bond length of 2.147 Å are similar to those reported for Ag1 complexes with the homologous protonated diaminoalkane ligands. In addition, the distance Ag1−O4W (2.626 Å) indicates that there is covalent interaction between the Ag1 ion and the O4W of water; the angles N25−Ag1−O4W and N27−Ag1−O4W are 92.78° and 94.52°, respectively (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Polyrotaxane [Ag(H2O)(C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)3H2O (1)

It is expected that the structure of the compound 1 is formed with linking by transition metal ions through the coordination with the pyridyl nitrogen atom of the pseudorotaxane C4Nn @Q[6], so generating a polyrotaxane or molecular necklace. Therefore, the reaction of the pseudorotaxane C4N3@TMeQ[6] with silver nitrate was carried out at pH ~ 8, and the compound 1, with a stoichiometry of [Ag(H2O)(C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)3H2O, was isolated. The X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that an infinite one-dimensional polyrotaxane with square-wave-like shape comprised of the pseudorotaxanes C4N3@TMeQ[6] and the Ag+ cations with a 1:1 ratio of pseudorotaxane to Ag+ ion is present in the crystal structure of compound 1 (Figure ). Each silver ion Ag1 is coordinated to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N25 and N27) from two adjacent pseudorotaxanes with nearly linear coordination geometry, and the N25-Ag1-N27 coordination angle is 171.97°. The two coordinated pyridine planes that have a dihedral angle of 53.60° and the Ag1-N25 bond length of 2.141 Å and the Ag1-N27 bond length of 2.147 Å are similar to those reported for Ag1 complexes with the homologous protonated diaminoalkane ligands. In addition, the distance Ag1-O4W (2.626 Å) indicates that there is covalent interaction between the Ag1 ion and the O4W of water; the angles N25-Ag1-O4W and N27-Ag1-O4W are 92.78° and 94.52°, respectively (Figure ).

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of one-dimensional polyrotaxane and with partial atom-numbering scheme. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  X-ray crystal structure of one-dimensional polyrotaxane and with partial atom-numbering scheme. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In the one-dimensional polyrotaxane, there are two similar pseudorotaxane C4N3@TMeQ[6] units A and B, with the distances between O2···N26, O3···N26, and O4···N26 in the pseudorotaxane A 2.820 Å, 2.898 Å, and 3.036 Å, respectively, and O11···N28 and O12···N28 in the pseudorotaxane B are 2.963 Å, 2.871 Å, respectively. These form hydrogen bonds and stabilize the host−guest structure (Figure ). The distance between two amino nitrogen atoms (N26) is 6.163 Å in unit A, and the distance between the two amino nitrogen atoms (N28) is 6.197 Å in unit B. This gives only a 0.034 Å difference. While the equivalent difference is up to 0.508 Å between the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N25) to the portal plane of TMeQ[6] in unit A and the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N27) to the portal plane of TMeQ[6] in unit B.
elements.clean_text: In the one-dimensional polyrotaxane, there are two similar pseudorotaxane C4N3@TMeQ[6] units A and B, with the distances between O2⋅⋅⋅N26, O3⋅⋅⋅N26, and O4⋅⋅⋅N26 in the pseudorotaxane A 2.820 Å, 2.898 Å, and 3.036 Å, respectively, and O11⋅⋅⋅N28 and O12⋅⋅⋅N28 in the pseudorotaxane B are 2.963 Å, 2.871 Å, respectively. These form hydrogen bonds and stabilize the host-guest structure (Figure ). The distance between two amino nitrogen atoms (N26) is 6.163 Å in unit A, and the distance between the two amino nitrogen atoms (N28) is 6.197 Å in unit B. This gives only a 0.034 Å difference. While the equivalent difference is up to 0.508 Å between the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N25) to the portal plane of TMeQ[6] in unit A and the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N27) to the portal plane of TMeQ[6] in unit B.

elements.content: The most interesting feature of the crystal structure is that the polyrotaxanes in compound 1 are arranged in such a way as to produce a two-dimensional network through the π−π stacking of pyridyl rings of the pseudorotaxanes A, with the center-to-center distance of two stacked pyridyl rings being 3.569 Å (Figure a). In addition, every four adjacent pseudorotaxane units (two A units and two B units) in the two-dimensional network form an octagon-shape cavity in which two nitrate anions are included. Through hydrogen bonding, the captured nitrate anion, latticed water molecules O1W, O2W, and O3W form a molecular chain (−O2W−O3W−(NO3 −)−O1W−O1W−(NO3 −)−O3W−O2W−), which links the two portal carbonyl oxygen O8 of two TMeQ[6] molecules belonging to the neighboring two-dimensional networks (Figure b). Thus, the neighboring two-dimensional networks are connected by a series of molecular chains and lead to the formation of stacking of the networks (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: The most interesting feature of the crystal structure is that the polyrotaxanes in compound 1 are arranged in such a way as to produce a two-dimensional network through the π-π stacking of pyridyl rings of the pseudorotaxanes A, with the center-to-center distance of two stacked pyridyl rings being 3.569 Å (Figure a). In addition, every four adjacent pseudorotaxane units (two A units and two B units) in the two-dimensional network form an octagon-shape cavity in which two nitrate anions are included. Through hydrogen bonding, the captured nitrate anion, latticed water molecules O1W, O2W, and O3W form a molecular chain (-O2W-O3W-(NO3 -)-O1W-O1W-(NO3 -)-O3W-O2W-), which links the two portal carbonyl oxygen O8 of two TMeQ[6] molecules belonging to the neighboring two-dimensional networks (Figure b). Thus, the neighboring two-dimensional networks are connected by a series of molecular chains and lead to the formation of stacking of the networks (Figure c).

elements.content: (a) Two-dimensional network of polyrotaxane through π−π stacking (inset: partial atom-numbering scheme in the network), (b) hydrogen bonding network which links the neighboring two-dimensional networks, (c) stacking of the two-dimensional networks. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Two-dimensional network of polyrotaxane through π-π stacking (inset: partial atom-numbering scheme in the network), (b) hydrogen bonding network which links the neighboring two-dimensional networks, (c) stacking of the two-dimensional networks. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: When the pseudorotaxane C4N4@TMeQ[6] was used to replace the pseudorotaxane C4N3@TMeQ[6] and the Ag+ cations were replaced by the Cu2+ dications, the compound 2 was obtained in which one can see a two-dimensional network comprising one-dimensional polyrotaxanes linked through hydrogen bonding (Figure ). There are two pseudorotaxane units, labeled A and B, linked by the Cu2+ cations. Each Cu2+ (Cu1) ion coordinates to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N26 and N28) of two adjacent pseudorotaxane units with nearly linear coordination geometry. Because the N26−Cu1−N28 coordination angle is 176.45°, the two coordinated pyridine planes are in almost the same plane, with a dihedral angle of 2.73°, and the Cu1−N26 and Cu1−N28 bond lengths are 1.997 Å and 1.992 Å, respectively. In addition, the Cu1 cation also coordinates to two water molecules and two chloride anions, giving distances for Cu1−O1W, Cu−O2W, Cu−Cl1, and Cu−Cl2 of 2.094 Å, 2.378 Å, 2.347 Å, and 2.447 Å, respectively. The two pseudorotaxane C4N4@TMeQ[6] units A and B in the one-dimensional polyrotaxane are structurally similar. The distances between O7···N25, O11···N25, and O12···N25 in the pseudorotaxane A are 2.952, 2.860, and 2.874 Å, respectively, and for O5···N27 and O6···N27 in the pseudorotaxane B are 2.850, 2.906 Å, respectively. These form hydrogen bonds and stabilize the host−guest pseudorotaxane structure. The distance between two amino nitrogen atoms (N25) is 6.278 Å in unit A, and the distance between the two amino nitrogen atoms (N28) is 6.247 Å in unit B, giving only a 0.021 Å difference. The difference is 0.193 Å between the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N26−N26: 16.355 Å) in unit A and the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N28−N28: 16.162 Å) in unit B.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Polyrotaxane [Cu(H2O)2Cl2(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2H2O (2)

When the pseudorotaxane C4N4@TMeQ[6] was used to replace the pseudorotaxane C4N3@TMeQ[6] and the Ag+ cations were replaced by the Cu2+ dications, the compound 2 was obtained in which one can see a two-dimensional network comprising one-dimensional polyrotaxanes linked through hydrogen bonding (Figure ). There are two pseudorotaxane units, labeled A and B, linked by the Cu2+ cations. Each Cu2+ (Cu1) ion coordinates to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N26 and N28) of two adjacent pseudorotaxane units with nearly linear coordination geometry. Because the N26-Cu1-N28 coordination angle is 176.45°, the two coordinated pyridine planes are in almost the same plane, with a dihedral angle of 2.73°, and the Cu1-N26 and Cu1-N28 bond lengths are 1.997 Å and 1.992 Å, respectively. In addition, the Cu1 cation also coordinates to two water molecules and two chloride anions, giving distances for Cu1-O1W, Cu-O2W, Cu-Cl1, and Cu-Cl2 of 2.094 Å, 2.378 Å, 2.347 Å, and 2.447 Å, respectively. The two pseudorotaxane C4N4@TMeQ[6] units A and B in the one-dimensional polyrotaxane are structurally similar. The distances between O7⋅⋅⋅N25, O11⋅⋅⋅N25, and O12⋅⋅⋅N25 in the pseudorotaxane A are 2.952, 2.860, and 2.874 Å, respectively, and for O5⋅⋅⋅N27 and O6⋅⋅⋅N27 in the pseudorotaxane B are 2.850, 2.906 Å, respectively. These form hydrogen bonds and stabilize the host-guest pseudorotaxane structure. The distance between two amino nitrogen atoms (N25) is 6.278 Å in unit A, and the distance between the two amino nitrogen atoms (N28) is 6.247 Å in unit B, giving only a 0.021 Å difference. The difference is 0.193 Å between the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N26-N26: 16.355 Å) in unit A and the distance of the pyridyl nitrogen (N28-N28: 16.162 Å) in unit B.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of a two-dimensional network comprising of one-dimensional polyrotaxanes through hydrogen bonding in the compound 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  X-ray crystal structure of a two-dimensional network comprising of one-dimensional polyrotaxanes through hydrogen bonding in the compound 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The lattice water molecule O3W plays an important role linking the adjacent polyrotaxane chains through hydrogen bonding with the portal carbonyl oxygen atoms (O2, O3 of a TMeQ[6]; and O8, O9 of a neighboring TMeQ[6]) in the compound 2. The distances O2···O3W, O3···O3W, O8···O3W, and O9···O3W are 2.962 Å, 2.889 Å, 2.881 Å, and 2.911 Å, respectively. These hydrogen bonding nets generate an infinite two-dimensional network in the compound 2.
elements.clean_text: The lattice water molecule O3W plays an important role linking the adjacent polyrotaxane chains through hydrogen bonding with the portal carbonyl oxygen atoms (O2, O3 of a TMeQ[6]; and O8, O9 of a neighboring TMeQ[6]) in the compound 2. The distances O2⋅⋅⋅O3W, O3⋅⋅⋅O3W, O8⋅⋅⋅O3W, and O9⋅⋅⋅O3W are 2.962 Å, 2.889 Å, 2.881 Å, and 2.911 Å, respectively. These hydrogen bonding nets generate an infinite two-dimensional network in the compound 2.

elements.content: Using the strategy of the formation of a pseudorotaxane by threading a Q[6] molecule with a “string” having suitable functional groups at both ends and then allowing the end functional groups of the pseudorotaxane to coordinate to metal centers, forming a coordination polymer, means that the metal ions generally coordinate to functional groups of the “string” guests, and the Q[6] molecules are not involved in the coordination with metal ions or the coordination polymer can still exist when the Q[6] molecules are omitted. However, the one-dimensional coordination polymer observed in compound 3 shows that the Ag+ metal ion presents a different coordination mode. One can see a tubular coordination polymer with alternating silver ions and pseudorotaxane C4N4@TMeQ[6] with a 1:2 ratio of pseudorotaxane to Ag+ ion. Instead of coordinating to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from the neighboring pseudorotaxanes, each Ag+ metal ion coordinates to only one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N14) from a pseudorotaxane, two carbonyl oxygen atoms (O3 and O4) from neighboring TMeQ[6], and two water molecules (O6W and O11W). Thus, each C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane links two neighboring C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxanes through the coordination of Ag1 to two carbonyl oxygen atoms of two neighboring TMeQ[6] molecules, giving bond lengths of Ag−N13, Ag−O3, and Ag−O4 as 2.243 Å, 2.447 Å, and 2.622 Å, respectively. Moreover, the bond lengths of Ag−O6W and Ag−O11W are 2.226 Å and 2.487 Å, respectively. Meanwhile the center TMeQ[6] molecule of the pseudorotaxane coordinates with two Ag1 ions which, in turn, coordinate to a pyridyl nitrogen atom (N14) from two neighboring pseudorotaxanes. The hydrogen bonds of O1···N14 (2.875 Å), O5···N14 (3.014 Å), and O6···N14 (2.954 Å) could further strengthen the C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane. In addition, the two protruded pyridyl moieties from two neighboring pseudorotaxanes lie parallel to each other through the π···π stacking and the center-to-center distance of two stacked pyridyl rings is 3.582 Å (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Polyrotaxane [Ag2(H2O)3(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2(NO3)14H2O (3)

Using the strategy of the formation of a pseudorotaxane by threading a Q[6] molecule with a "string" having suitable functional groups at both ends and then allowing the end functional groups of the pseudorotaxane to coordinate to metal centers, forming a coordination polymer, means that the metal ions generally coordinate to functional groups of the "string" guests, and the Q[6] molecules are not involved in the coordination with metal ions or the coordination polymer can still exist when the Q[6] molecules are omitted. However, the one-dimensional coordination polymer observed in compound 3 shows that the Ag+ metal ion presents a different coordination mode. One can see a tubular coordination polymer with alternating silver ions and pseudorotaxane C4N4@TMeQ[6] with a 1:2 ratio of pseudorotaxane to Ag+ ion. Instead of coordinating to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from the neighboring pseudorotaxanes, each Ag+ metal ion coordinates to only one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N14) from a pseudorotaxane, two carbonyl oxygen atoms (O3 and O4) from neighboring TMeQ[6], and two water molecules (O6W and O11W). Thus, each C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane links two neighboring C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxanes through the coordination of Ag1 to two carbonyl oxygen atoms of two neighboring TMeQ[6] molecules, giving bond lengths of Ag-N13, Ag-O3, and Ag-O4 as 2.243 Å, 2.447 Å, and 2.622 Å, respectively. Moreover, the bond lengths of Ag-O6W and Ag-O11W are 2.226 Å and 2.487 Å, respectively. Meanwhile the center TMeQ[6] molecule of the pseudorotaxane coordinates with two Ag1 ions which, in turn, coordinate to a pyridyl nitrogen atom (N14) from two neighboring pseudorotaxanes. The hydrogen bonds of O1⋅⋅⋅N14 (2.875 Å), O5⋅⋅⋅N14 (3.014 Å), and O6⋅⋅⋅N14 (2.954 Å) could further strengthen the C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane. In addition, the two protruded pyridyl moieties from two neighboring pseudorotaxanes lie parallel to each other through the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking and the center-to-center distance of two stacked pyridyl rings is 3.582 Å (Figure ).

elements.content: Crystal structure of one-dimensional coordination polyrotaxane in the compound 3. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structure of one-dimensional coordination polyrotaxane in the compound 3. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: It should be noted that the Ag+ metal coordination selectivity for the oxygen carbonyls of the methyl-substituted glycoluril moieties further confirm the early suggestion that the solid state affinity of the metal ion for the carbonyl oxygen atom of the substituted glycoluril moiety indicates a likely increased electron density as a consequence of the electron donating effect of the alkyl substituents. The bond length of Ag−O3 (methyl-substituted glycoluril moiety) being shorter by 0.175 Å than that of Ag−O4 could be further evidence of Ag+ metal coordination selectivity for the oxygen carbonyl.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that the Ag+ metal coordination selectivity for the oxygen carbonyls of the methyl-substituted glycoluril moieties further confirm the early suggestion that the solid state affinity of the metal ion for the carbonyl oxygen atom of the substituted glycoluril moiety indicates a likely increased electron density as a consequence of the electron donating effect of the alkyl substituents. The bond length of Ag-O3 (methyl-substituted glycoluril moiety) being shorter by 0.175 Å than that of Ag-O4 could be further evidence of Ag+ metal coordination selectivity for the oxygen carbonyl.

elements.content: The water molecule O11W, which coordinates to the Ag+ cation, plays an important role in the connection of the tubular coordination polymers. The distance between two adjacent O11W atoms from the neighboring tubular coordination polymers is 2.908 Å because they interact with each other through hydrogen bonding. In addition, the methyl group decorated on the surface of the TMeQ[6] could form a C−H···π interaction with the adjacent pyridyl ring of the neighboring tubular coordination polymer. The distances between the substituted methyl and the pyridyl ring are in the range of 3.369−3.551 Å (C19, C20 to the plane of the pyridyl ring). The combination of the hydrogen bonding between water molecules (O11W) and the C−H···π interactions of the substituted methyl groups to the pyridyl rings leads to the formation of a two-dimensional network consisting of the tubular polymers (Figure a). Between the two-dimensional networks, one can see complicated hydrogen bonding nets consisting of nitrate anions, latticed water molecules, coordinated water molecules (to Ag1), and portal carbonyl oxygens of TMeQ[6], which leads to the stacking of the two-dimensional networks (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: The water molecule O11W, which coordinates to the Ag+ cation, plays an important role in the connection of the tubular coordination polymers. The distance between two adjacent O11W atoms from the neighboring tubular coordination polymers is 2.908 Å because they interact with each other through hydrogen bonding. In addition, the methyl group decorated on the surface of the TMeQ[6] could form a C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction with the adjacent pyridyl ring of the neighboring tubular coordination polymer. The distances between the substituted methyl and the pyridyl ring are in the range of 3.369-3.551 Å (C19, C20 to the plane of the pyridyl ring). The combination of the hydrogen bonding between water molecules (O11W) and the C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions of the substituted methyl groups to the pyridyl rings leads to the formation of a two-dimensional network consisting of the tubular polymers (Figure a). Between the two-dimensional networks, one can see complicated hydrogen bonding nets consisting of nitrate anions, latticed water molecules, coordinated water molecules (to Ag1), and portal carbonyl oxygens of TMeQ[6], which leads to the stacking of the two-dimensional networks (Figure b).

elements.content: (a) View of two-dimensional network comprising of the polyrotaxanes, (b) stacking of the two-dimensional networks in the compound 3. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) View of two-dimensional network comprising of the polyrotaxanes, (b) stacking of the two-dimensional networks in the compound 3. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Kim and co-workers first introduced the strategy to synthesize a polyrotaxanes in Q[n] chemistry, in which a polyrotaxanes is formed from a pseudorotaxane by threading a molecular “bead” with a “string” having suitable functional groups at both ends and then to allow the end functional groups of the pseudorotaxane to coordinate to metal centers forming a coordination polymer. The metal ions used in this strategy are mostly Ag(I) and Cu(II), and they play a role of connection of pseudorotaxane through direct coordination to the end functional groups of the pseudorotaxane and lead to the formation of a linear or network polyrotaxanes. Instead of Q[6], a methyl-substituted cucurbituril, TMeQ[6] was used as the molecular “bead” in this work, and Ag(I) and Cu(II) were used to link the pseudorotaxane of C4N4 or C4N3@TMeQ[6]. Generally, the formed polyrotaxanes are one-dimensional coordination polymers. In particular, in the C4N3@TMeQ[6] polyrotaxane (1), a two-dimensional network is first observed in the Q[6]-based polyrotaxanes. The driving force for the formation of such a two-dimensional network is the π···π stacking of the protruded pyridyl moieties from the C4N3@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane. In the C4N4@TMeQ[6] polyrotaxane (3), the TMeQ[6] “beads” play important roles in the construction of the polyrotaxane. The metal ions (Ag1) coordinate to only one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N14) from a C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane and two carbonyl oxygen atoms (O3 and O4) of neighboring TMeQ[6] from the neighboring C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane. Thus, a tubular C4N4@TMeQ[6] polyrotaxane is formed. It should be noted that the solid state affinity of the metal ion for the carbonyl oxygen atom of the substituted glycoluril moiety could be attributed to the increased electron density as a consequence of the electron donating effect of the alkyl substituents. The metal coordination selectivity for the oxygen carbonyls of the alkyl-substituted glycoluril moieties of the alkyl-substituted Q[n] is being examined further to ascertain the predictability of ring formation relative to substitution.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Kim and co-workers first introduced the strategy to synthesize a polyrotaxanes in Q[n] chemistry, in which a polyrotaxanes is formed from a pseudorotaxane by threading a molecular "bead" with a "string" having suitable functional groups at both ends and then to allow the end functional groups of the pseudorotaxane to coordinate to metal centers forming a coordination polymer. The metal ions used in this strategy are mostly Ag(I) and Cu(II), and they play a role of connection of pseudorotaxane through direct coordination to the end functional groups of the pseudorotaxane and lead to the formation of a linear or network polyrotaxanes. Instead of Q[6], a methyl-substituted cucurbituril, TMeQ[6] was used as the molecular "bead" in this work, and Ag(I) and Cu(II) were used to link the pseudorotaxane of C4N4 or C4N3@TMeQ[6]. Generally, the formed polyrotaxanes are one-dimensional coordination polymers. In particular, in the C4N3@TMeQ[6] polyrotaxane (1), a two-dimensional network is first observed in the Q[6]-based polyrotaxanes. The driving force for the formation of such a two-dimensional network is the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking of the protruded pyridyl moieties from the C4N3@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane. In the C4N4@TMeQ[6] polyrotaxane (3), the TMeQ[6] "beads" play important roles in the construction of the polyrotaxane. The metal ions (Ag1) coordinate to only one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N14) from a C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane and two carbonyl oxygen atoms (O3 and O4) of neighboring TMeQ[6] from the neighboring C4N4@TMeQ[6] pseudorotaxane. Thus, a tubular C4N4@TMeQ[6] polyrotaxane is formed. It should be noted that the solid state affinity of the metal ion for the carbonyl oxygen atom of the substituted glycoluril moiety could be attributed to the increased electron density as a consequence of the electron donating effect of the alkyl substituents. The metal coordination selectivity for the oxygen carbonyls of the alkyl-substituted glycoluril moieties of the alkyl-substituted Q[n] is being examined further to ascertain the predictability of ring formation relative to substitution.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format; comparison of the Mulliken atomic charges on the carbonyl oxygens, structur of TMeQ[6], crystallographic data for 1−7, and results. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of TMeQ[6] (0.41 g, 0.40 mmol) and [(H2 C4N3)(NO3)2] (0.0155 g, 0.40 mmol) in water (15 mL) was heated with stirring at 50 °C for 2 h. The solution was filtered, and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for a period of 2 weeks. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were obtained from the solution with a yield of 30%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.83 (s, 2H), 8.54 (d, 2H), 8.22 (d, 2H), 7.50 (t, 2H), 5.68(d, 12H), 5.52(d, 8H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 2.41 (t, 4H), 1.71 (s, 12H), 0.47 (m, 4H). AgNO3 (13.6 mg, 0.08 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (128 mg, 0.080 mmol) in 10 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8−9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 1 week produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 1 with a yield of 40%. Anal. Calcd for C56H74N29O19Ag: C, 42.97; H, 4.77; N, 25.95. Found: C, 43.06; H, 4.48; N, 26.58.

Preparation of [Cu(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub>(<bold>C4N4</bold>)(TMeQ[6])]2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

Crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were prepared by dissolving TMeQ[6] (0.84 g, 0.80 mmol) and [(H2 C4N4)(NO3)2] (0.0320 g, 0.80 mmol) in water (30 mL). The solution was heated for 2 h and then allowed to stand at room temperature. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were obtained from the solution over a period of one week with a yield of 35%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.83 (s, 2H), 8.54 (d, 2H), 8.22 (d, 2H), 7.50 (t, 2H), 5.68 (d, 12H), 5.52 (d, 8H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 2.41 (t, 4H), 1.71 (s, 12H), 0.47 (m, 4H). CuCl2 (13.5 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted to pH = 8−9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 2 weeks produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 2 with a yield of 35%. Anal. Calcd for C56H74N28O16CuCl2: C, 43.97; H, 4.88; N, 25.64. Found: C, 44.17; H, 4.68; N, 25.84.

Preparation of [Ag<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>(<bold>C4N4</bold>)(TMeQ[6])]2(NO<sub>3</sub>)14H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

AgNO3 (17.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8−9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over 2 days produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 3 with a yield of 25%. Anal. Calcd for C56H100N30O35Ag2: C, 34.15; H, 5.12; N, 21.34. Found: C, 34.27; H, 4.88; N, 22.84.

A mixture of TMeQ[6] (0.41 g, 0.40 mmol) and [(H2 C4N3)(NO3)2] (0.0155 g, 0.40 mmol) in water (15 mL) was heated with stirring at 50 °C for 2 h. The solution was filtered, and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for a period of 2 weeks. AgNO3 (13.6 mg, 0.08 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N3)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (128 mg, 0.080 mmol) in 10 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8-9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 1 week produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 1 with a yield of 40%. Anal. Preparation of [Cu(H2O)2Cl2(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2H2O (2)

Crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were prepared by dissolving TMeQ[6] (0.84 g, 0.80 mmol) and [(H2 C4N4)(NO3)2] (0.0320 g, 0.80 mmol) in water (30 mL). The solution was heated for 2 h and then allowed to stand at room temperature. Colorless X-ray quality crystals of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 were obtained from the solution over a period of one week with a yield of 35%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.83 (s, 2H), 8.54 (d, 2H), 8.22 (d, 2H), 7.50 (t, 2H), 5.68 (d, 12H), 5.52 (d, 8H), 4.32 (d, 12H), 2.41 (t, 4H), 1.71 (s, 12H), 0.47 (m, 4H). CuCl2 (13.5 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted to pH = 8-9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over a period of 2 weeks produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 2 with a yield of 35%. Anal. Calcd for C56H74N28O16CuCl2: C, 43.97; H, 4.88; N, 25.64. Found: C, 44.17; H, 4.68; N, 25.84.

Preparation of [Ag2(H2O)3(C4N4)(TMeQ[6])]2(NO3)14H2O (3)

AgNO3 (17.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added to a solution of the compound [(H2 C4N4)(TMeQ[6])](NO3)2 (150 mg, 0.096 mmol) in 15 mL of water, and the solution was adjusted at pH = 8-9 using ammonia solution. Diffusion of methanol into the reaction mixture over 2 days produces colorless X-ray quality crystals of 3 with a yield of 25%. Anal. Calcd for C56H100N30O35Ag2: C, 34.15; H, 5.12; N, 21.34. Found: C, 34.27; H, 4.88; N, 22.84.

metadata.title: Use of Silver(I) and Copper(II) Ions to Assist the Self-Assembly of Polyrotaxanes Incorporating Symmetrical α,α′,δ,δ′-Tetramethyl-cucurbit[6]uril
